body.p:
With reference to our conversation of yesterday
I have concluded that as Mr Leeser labors under great
misapprehension as to my course of action in respect
to the office of Hazan to the Philadelphia congregation—it
might be quite compatible with your friendly feelings
for both parties were you to acquaint him when you
again write him that I have most emphatically
denied and ever must deny to you and to every one that
I have ever thought done or said anything that could to
the best of my knowledge and intent, injure in the
remotest degree Mr Leeser and his cause. I am quite
aware as I stated to you yesterday that Mr L. considers
I have agrieved him but I am also equally certain
that I have no little cause of surprise mortification and
sorrow not to say anger at the way Mr L has treated me.
If after four years (on my part) agreeable communion
we have become now estranged, I must not and will not
let Mr Leeser or any one else suppose that this
has been through my fault entirely. I may say
through my wickedness, for if the charges
Mr Leeser brings directly or indirectly against me
are true. I do not refer to anything he may have
written

written you, but what I have learnt from others, if these
can be substantiated by him in opposition—not
to mere assertion only, but to the documentary proofs
of denial in my possession then I certainly have
acted as one unworthy Israelite and false friend—which
I most solemnly deny. Mr Leeser if I
understand you aright left it to your option
to show me what he says about me in certain
letters to you. As you know, I have not heard
or seen the particulars of those letters, but you
are quite at liberty to show Mr Leeser these few lines
to which I will add that I have never sought or
made use of Swiss mercenaries either of the press
or of the K. K Mickveh Israel as I hear is his belief
and if I appear to have been associated with a
party it is because I am not residing in Philadelphia,
the only partisanship I have ever thought permissible
to me, being the support of those of the Congregation
who might consider me worthy to fill the office
when Mr Leeser was by his own word and deed
no longer a candidate for the office. I also most
emphatically deny that any one here or abroad
ever dissuaded me by word or letter from
visiting Philadelphia. Mr Leeser I believe
is under the impression I was so advised
All letters on the subject including copies
of my own, I have in my possession and these you

or any one else can inspect, though I cannot suppose
that any of my friends knowing me and not being “hasty
to judge” will doubt my assertions. Had any one whom I
esteem less than Mr Leeser formed these notions of me
I would perhaps not care were he disabused or
not of them, but I don't think I ought to suffer
unworthy stigmas to fasten on me when conscious
of my innocence; and I therefore repeat you can (if disposed)
send this to Mr Leeser that he may see I (and I am
happy to say many friends) cannot admit that I am
the guilty thing he seems to consider me

Of course if, after seeing this my disclaimer of the wrongs
imputed to me, Mr Leeser is willing to admit to you that he
may have been deceived with respect to me; I shall, as his
junior waive the consideration that he is yet to reply to
a letter of mine he received some six months back and I will
address him if he like giving a full detail of circumstances
in my justification of the course pursued by me, of if he
will wait for the more convenient opportunity of a personal interview
(and I cannot suppose that he so “takes me in his heart” that he
will not see me when possible, but that he is rather willing to
“reprove” me showing me how wrong I have been if he can, and then
forgive me) when I can have with me certain documents indispensable
for elucidation, and if he can “hold one guiltless” till then, I shall in such
case consider myself justified in addressing him on matters perhaps
more acceptable under present circumstances.
